title: 113_hr5790
content: The Act titled "Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014" introduces prize competitions for improving health outcomes and reducing federal expenditures under the Public Health Service Act. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 aims to improve health outcomes and reduce Federal expenditures on health programs through prize competitions. Within 6 months of enactment, the Director of NIH will identify 3 to 5 diseases or health conditions with significant Federal spending on prevention and treatment activities but limited research investment compared to other similar diseases. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 directs the Director of NIH to design prize competitions within 12 months to achieve health goals for diseases with high Federal spending on prevention and treatment activities. Competitors will cooperate to innovate and prizes will be awarded accordingly. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 mandates prize competitions to promote innovative solutions for health goals. Competitors will be judged based on the promise of their innovations and the effectiveness of their solutions. The design of the competitions must be realistic, unbiased, inclusive, and address areas of unmet need. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 mandates prize competitions to promote innovative solutions for health goals. Competitors will be judged based on the promise of their innovations and the effectiveness of their solutions. The Director of NIH will consult with experts and relevant federal agencies, and award contracts for a simulation of the prize competitions. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 requires prize competitions to be conducted based on designs developed in consultation with experts and agency heads. The Director of NIH will use simulations to assess the effectiveness of the designs and make adjustments as needed within 21 months of enactment. A report on the results of the simulation and any adjustments made must be submitted to Congress. The Director of NIH will implement prize competitions based on designs developed under the Health Prizes Act, requiring competitors to demonstrate effectiveness over a maximum of 5 years. The Secretary and Commissioner may provide guidance and testing facilities. A total of 5 prize competitions will be conducted, with a limit of 2 per disease or condition. The Director will track and report on the competitions. The Director of NIH will collect information on the medical efficacy and impact on Federal expenditures of innovations funded through prize competitions. A report will be submitted to Congress annually for 5 years. The government cannot acquire intellectual property without participant consent, but may negotiate licenses for its use. Authorization of Appropriations for prize competitions under subsection (e) is set at $50,000,000. A minimum of 70 percent of assistance awarded to private entities must be given as prizes to competitors. Certain prizes for improving health outcomes are excluded from recipients' gross income. The amendment excludes certain prizes for improving health outcomes from taxable income under section 409K of the Public Health Service Act. Effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
